Graphical abstract Palladium (Pd) complexes supported on the polymers have been widely used in various organic syntheses endeavors because of their thermal stability, high catalytic activities and recyclability. This article provides contemporary advancements in the deployment of polymer-supported Pd complexes (PSP complexes) in Sonogashira coupling reactions (SCR) of halobenzenes with alkynes. Although most of the reports on SCR are focused on aryl iodides, newer methodologies with supported Pd enable the activation of other aryl halides, especially chlorides, which are discussed in this review. Keywords Sonogashira coupling reaction Polymer-supported Pd complexes Solid support Catalysis Recycling 1 Introduction The named reaction developed by Sonogashira et al. in 1975, Sonogashira coupling reactions (SCR) of vinyl or aryl halides with terminal alkynes is a unique and extremely effective reaction for the creation of CC bond between C(sp2) and C(sp) atoms [1]. This reaction is applied in the polymer and pharmaceutical industries, material science and in the preparation of heterocyclic compounds, biologically active substances and natural products [1–9]. The SCR between halobenzenes and terminal alkynes is conventionally performed by a homogeneous Pd catalyst and CuCl (CuBr or CuI) as the co-catalyst, stoichiometric amounts of different bases and hazardous phosphine ligands in benzene, DMF or THF as solvent [10–12]. The disadvantages of this reaction include harsher reaction conditions, longer reaction times, inert atmosphere requirements, application of non-green solvents, expensive and non-recyclable homogeneous Pd catalysts and air- or moisture-sensitive ligands, tedious work-up and the formation of environmentally detrimental diyne side products through oxidative dimerization of in situ prepared copper acetylide. These drawbacks have been to large extent circumvented by utilizing heterogeneous, and recyclable catalysts [13–36]; several researchers, including our own group, have recently reported the application of heterogeneous catalysts in the SCR under ligand-, amine-, organic solvent and copper-free conditions to remove the obstacles encountered with the conventional methods [37–46]. Polymer-supported Pd (PSP) complexes are one of the popular heterogeneous catalysts, which have been utilized extensively under ligand- and Cu-free conditions; these recyclable catalysts can be easily synthesized using assorted ligands [47,48]. The SCR have been reviewed using different catalysts such as Ru, Cu, Au, Pd nanoparticles (NPs), Pd-Fe3O4 NPs, graphene based nanocomposites [45,46] and Pd complexes [49]. Nevertheless, the SCR using PSP complexes have not yet been appraised. In continuation of our ongoing work on the coupling reactions [50–55], we endeavored to document the recent advancements in the preparation and application of PSP complexes in the SCR. 2 Polymer-supported Pd (PSP) complexes for Sonogashira coupling reactions (SCR) There are various reports on the application of PSP complexes in the SCR for the creation of C(sp)-C(sp2) bond [56–103]. Buchmeiser et al. reported an effective method for the formulation of stable Pd complexes using N-acyl substituted bispyrimidylamines in 2001 [56] and PSP complex (1) was prepared by polymerization of N-norborn-2-ene-5-ylbis(pyrimid-2-yl)carbamide through Mo(N-2,6-i-Pr2)(CHCMe2Ph)(OCMe(CF3)2)2 and consequent cross-linking with 1,4,4a,5,8,8a-hexahydro-1,4,5,8-exo-endo-dimethanonaphthalene (DMN-H6), followed by interaction with H2PdCl4 (Scheme 1 ). The application of resin (1) as a stable catalyst in the SCR (Scheme 2 ) was investigated at low Pd loading (0.007-0.004 mol. %) in THF solvent in the absence or presence of tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (TBAB); this additive being necessary especially for aryl chlorides. Soon thereafter, Bräse et al. used polymer supported triazenes as organic supports for anchoring of Pd complexes [57] wherein the polymer supported Pd triazene complex (2) in the presence of CuI showed significant catalytic performance in the SCR of phenylacetylene with iodobenzene in dioxane with a 71% yield at ambient temperature (Scheme 3 ). In 2003, Plenio et al. synthesized a Pd complex with the phosphinated polymer from (1-Ad)2P substituted poly(methylstyrene) (3) and Pd(PhCN)2Cl2 as the Pd source [58]. The polymer loaded with electron rich -CH2P(1-Ad)2 functionalities (3) was synthesized by anionic polymerization of 4-methylstyrene, bromination with Br2 followed by reaction with (1-Ad)2PH (Scheme 4 ). Moderate to high yields were obtained using this complex for SCR in presence of HN i Pr2 in toluene at 60 °C (Scheme 5 ). Interestingly, recycling was performed by membrane separation and the catalyst could be reused for nine cycles with high efficiency. The preparation of PSP complex 5 as a relatively efficient catalytic system [59] has been reported; complex was prepared from trans-di(μ-acetato)-bis[2-(diphenylphosphino)-4-vinylbenzyl]dipalladium(II) (4) by heating with styrene at 70 °C (Scheme 6 ). The palladacycle 5 was applied as a catalyst in a series of SCR (Scheme 7 ) the salient advantages for the complex catalyst being high product yields and its easy separation and recyclability. Nájera et al. synthesized a PCP complex (7) (Scheme 8 ) and used it in the SCR (Scheme 9 ) [60]. The Pd complex (7) was synthesized by the reaction of polymer supported ligand (6) and a methanolic solution of Na2PdCl4 at ambient temperature; polymer 7, in turn, was prepared by reacting di-(2-pyridyl)methylamine with poly(styrene-alt-maleic anhydride) resin in refluxing acetone-water mixture (1:2) for a day. Lee et al. prepared recoverable Pd-complex based on polymer supported N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) (8) (Scheme 10 ) [61]; the polymer structure comprising imidazolium as the heterocycle on polymer-supported NHC surface. The efficiency of the catalyst (8) was examined in the SCR under ambient conditions (Scheme 11 ) wherein it could be recycled four times with high efficiency. In 2007, Bandini and co-workers applied an electrodeposition process to prepare polymer supported thiophene Pd-complex (DAT3-Pd(ƞ3-C3H5)][BF4] (9) (Scheme 12 ), which was then used as a recyclable catalyst in the SCR [62]. The application of (9) in the reaction of 2-fluoro-1-iodobenzene with ethynylbenzene afforded the product in good yield under phosphine-, copper-, and solvent-free conditions (Scheme 13 ). Bakherad et al. used (PS-dpp-Pd(0)) polymer supported Pd(0) complex in the SCR (Scheme 14 ) [63]. The Pd complex was prepared by the interaction of diphenylphosphinoethane with polystyrene resin, followed by the treatment of ensuing phosphinated polystyrene with [PdCl2(PhCN)2] solution in ethanol and lastly reduction using NH2NH2.H2O at 50 °C (Scheme 15 ); high product yields were secured and the complex was reused several times. Another Pd complex catalyst was prepared by the same group (Scheme 16 ) [64] wherein the ethylenediamine-based PSP complex, [PS-en-Pd(II)], was synthesized by reaction of polystyrene resin with ethylenediamine under reflux in MeCN solvent, followed by the interaction of aminated polystyrene with ethanolic solution of [PdCl2(C6H5CN)2]; 6-(substituted benzyl)imidazo[2,1-b][1,3]thiazole was synthesized via SCR (Scheme 17 ) using Et3N and [PS-en-Pd(II)] in DMF solvent. The catalyst was reused for five successive cycles. The same group, in an extension of earlier work, studied catalytic activity of [PS-en-Pd(II)] for the synthesis of 2-benzylimidazo[2,1-b][1,3]benzothiazoles by SCR and subsequent cyclization reaction (Scheme 18 ) [65]. The application of [PS-en-Pd(II)] was also investigated in the preparation of 2-benzylimidazo[2,1-b]pyridines via SCR in presence of CuI (Scheme 19 ) [66]; the catalyst was reused for five successive cycles. In 2010, Islam et al. reported a protocol for the fabrication of anthranilic acid-based PSP complex, PS-Pd(II)-anthra (Scheme 20 ) [67] which displayed catalytic activity in the SCR deploying Et3N in DMF (Scheme 21 ). However, this method failed in the case of chlorobenzenes. Additionally, they also described the application of polystyrene anchored Pd(II) azo complex, synthesized by reacting 1-nitroso-2-naphthol with polymeric amine under reflux conditions in methanol solvent and subsequent reaction with glacial AcOH/Pd(OAc)2 (Scheme 22 ); aryl halides reacted well with ethynylbenzene in water using Et3N and TBAB as the base and additive, respectively, at 80 °C (Scheme 23 ) [68]. A simple procedure for the fabrication of thiosemicarbazone-based PSP complex [PS-ppdot-Pd(II)] was described by reacting 1-phenyl-1,2-propanedione-2-oxime thiosemi-carbazone (PPDOT) and chloromethylated polystyrene at 100 °C for 20 h. The ensued PPDOT functionalized polymer and its reaction with [PdCl2(PhCN)2] was explored under refluxing ethanol (Scheme 24 ) [69]. PS-ppdot-Pd(II) catalyzed SCR using Et3N or pyridine as the base at ambient temperature (Scheme 25 ); only moderate yields were obtained for aromatic chlorides although the catalyst was could be reused for four successive cycles. Polystyrene-poly-(ethylene glycol) (PS-PEG) was deployed as the organic support for anchoring palladium-phosphine complex (Scheme 26 ) [70] wherein the ensuing amphiphilic PS-PEG resin bound triarylphosphine ligand (10) was used in copper-free SCR in water (Scheme 27 ). The catalyst was reused for successive six cycles. The same group reported another method for the SCR (Scheme 28 ) using diethylenetriamine-based PSP complex [PS-nap-Pd(II)] [71]; [PS-nap-Pd(II)] was prepared by reacting polystyrene-N,N-bis(naphthylideneimino)diethylenetriamine (PS-nap) with [PdCl2(PhCN)2] in refluxing EtOH (Scheme 29 ). The catalyst was reused for ten consecutive cycles. Islam et al. prepared a catalytically active polymer-immobilized Pd(II) Schiff base complex (Scheme 30 ) [72] which performed efficiently in the phosphine-free SCR (Scheme 31 ). The catalyst was reused for straight five times. An effective catalyst for SCR using FDU-NHC/Pd(II) complex (Scheme 32 ) was reportedly synthesized by anchoring N-methylimidazole as NHC onto FDU (Fudan University)-15 mesopolymer [73]; phosphine free FDU-NHC/Pd(II) complex catalyzed SCR (Scheme 33 ). Although this phosphine-free and stable catalyst was not appropriate for aryl chlorides, but good yields were produced in the terminal alkynes reaction with aryl iodides or bromides with reuse exceeding ten times. Macrocyclic Schiff base-based PSP complex (11) was introduced as a novel, robust and thermally stable catalyst (Scheme 34 ) [74] and exhibited high catalytic performance in the SCR (Scheme 35 ) with only a 0.5 mol. % Pd loading; catalytic system could be repeatedly used for five cycles with high efficiency. Yet another PCP Schiff base complex (12) was prepared by reacting polystyrene amine with benzaldehyde under reflux in dry toluene for 72 h., followed by the reaction of synthesized polymer Schiff base ligand with palladium acetate in AcOH at 80 °C for 10 h (Scheme 36 ) [75]. The complex obtained with 1.0 mol. % Pd loading (12) could catalyze the SCR under ligand- and Cu-free conditions using Et3N and TBAB in DMF/H2O mixture (Scheme 37 ); catalyst could be reused for successive six cycles. In 2011, Tamami et al. reported the fabrication of polymeric NHC grafted silica-supported Pd NPs (Si-PNHC-Pd) [76]. The novel Si-PNHC-Pd (Scheme 38 ) displayed remarkable activity in the SCR (Scheme 39 ). The catalyst was successively reused 12 times, distinguished features being thermal stability and high recyclability with TON 2130. The synthesis of super paramagnetic NPs (γ-Fe2O3/polymer) supported dendritic catalyst based on phosphine Pd(II) complex [77] was reported wherein the assembly of catalyst (13) secured via the reaction of carboxylic acid groups of the γ-Fe2O3/polymer with the amino functionalities (Scheme 40 ). The ensuing catalyst catalyzed the copper-free SCR in the presence of a surfactant where the colloidal dispersion of surfactant particles played a significant part in the cross-coupling yield (Scheme 41 ). Furthermore, a similar effect was obtained by methanol reaction media compared with the aqueous media containing the surfactant. Thiosemicarbazone-based PSP complex [PS-PPdot-Pd(0)] (Scheme 42 ) was introduced by Bakherad et al. [78]. This copper- and solvent-free SCR using [PS-PPdot-Pd(0)] and Et3N at ambient temperature was investigated (Scheme 43 ); high product yields were produced and the complex was reused for several cycles. Similarly, the preparation of the phenyldithiocarbazate-based PSP complex (14) was attained by reacting phenylhydrazine with carbon disulfide and chloromethylated polystyrene using KOH (Scheme 44 ) [79]. The catalyst (14) was evaluated in copper-free SCR in pyridine at ambient temperature for 3 h (Scheme 45 ). A novel furfural-functionalized polymer grafted with Pd(II) (PS-Pd(II)-furfural complex) was reported for coupling reactions of different aryl halides with organo boronic acid, alkene, amine and alkyne [80]. The complex was prepared via the reaction of furfural with macroporous amino polystyrene and subsequent complexation with Pd(OAc)2 (Scheme 46 ). The PS-Pd(II)-furfural complex reportedly found to be an inexpensive, stable and recyclable (5 cycles) catalyst for the SCR (Scheme 47 ). A simple protocol for the preparation of a triazole-based PSP complex [PS-tazo-Pd(II)] has been described (Scheme 48 ) [81]. PS-tazo-Pd(II) was used a reusable complex in the copper-free SCR to deliver the desirable products in high yields; reaction could be accomplished at ambient temperature in basic (K2CO3) water as a solvent (Scheme 49 ). The same group reported dithizone-based PSP complex [PS-dtz-Pd(II)], prepared by reacting dithizone with chloromethylated polystyrene, followed by the subsequent reaction of the dithizone functionalized polymer (15) with [PdCl2(C6H5CN)2] solution in refluxing ethanol (Scheme 50 ); catalyst performed well in aqueous SCR at ambient temperature (Scheme 51 ) [82]. Thiopseudourea-based PSP complex [PS-tsu-Pd(II)] (17) (Scheme 52 ) was developed as a catalyst by Keesara and co-workers for the aqueous SCR using Et3N base at ambient temperature (Scheme 53 ), high product yields were obtained and the complex was reused with good recyclability (10 cycles) [83]. The preparation of triazine-based PSP complex [PS-triazine-Pd(II)] was reported by anchoring a triazine derivative on polystyrene, followed by its complexation with PdCl2(C6H5CN)2 (Scheme 54 ) [84]. The [PS-triazine-Pd(II)] showed high catalytic activity in the solvent-free SCR (Scheme 55 ); catalyst could be quickly removed and recycled for 5 successive times. In 2014, Nasrollahzadeh et al. reported the fabrication and catalytic prowess of tetrazole-based PSP complex [PS-tet-Pd(II)] (Scheme 56 ) [85] in the phosphine-free SCR in water (Scheme 57 ); catalyst was reused for several successive cycles. Polystyrene immobilized Pd(II) pyridine complex, [PS-mapy-Pd(II)] was prepared by anchoring 2-methylaminopyridine on polystyrene (Scheme 58 ) [86]; ensuing recyclable (5 cycles) catalyst was evaluated in the SCR (Scheme 59 ). The preparation of a novel, reusable and efficient PSP complex was described by Heravi et al. [87] wherein PdCl2 was supported on modified poly(styrene-co-maleic anhydride) (SMA) with 2-aminothiazole (Scheme 60 ). The ensuing catalyst SMI-PdCl2 catalyzed SCR of aryl halides and various terminal acetylenes (Scheme 61 ). Another group prepared Fe3O4@SiO2-polymer-imid-Pd magnetic complex (Scheme 62 ) and studied them in the SCR (Scheme 63 ) [88]. Fe3O4@SiO2 nanosphere was prepared using tetraethoxysilane (TEOS), Fe3O4 magnetite nanoparticles and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as the silica source, core, and surfactant, respectively. Then, Fe3O4@SiO2 was adorned with polymeric NHC/Pd and this complex could be reused for six successive cycles. Merrifield resin (PS) reinforced air-stable Pd NHC complex was investigated in the presence of a spacer (Pd-NHC@SP-PS) and absence of a spacer (Pd-NHC@PS) [89]. These complexes were synthesized via immobilization of an ionic liquid on the surface of polymer and the reaction of the ensuing amended polymer with Pd salt (Scheme 64 ). The functionalized PS-SP resin was prepared by reacting 6-chlorohexanol with commercially available PS using NaH in THF for 48 h. The catalyst was evaluated in the solvent- and copper-free SCR (Scheme 65 ). Apparently, the activity of Pd-NHC@SP-PS catalyst was more than that of Pd-NHC@PS because of the greater accessibility of active catalytic sites. In addition, both the catalysts prepared could be reused for successive six cycles. Tamami et al. successfully immobilized Pd NPs onto modified cross-linked polystyrene (Scheme 66 ) [90] and the polymeric Pd(0) complex was then used in the SCR in THF solvent at 100 °C (Scheme 67 ). The recycling of the catalyst was shown in five successive cycles. Thogiti et al. reported the fabrication of thiopseudourea-based PSP complex supported on the polymer (PS-bpt-Pd) (Scheme 68 ) [91]. Using PS-bpt-Pd catalyst and Et3N base, the SCR (Scheme 69 ) was then performed and the products were created in good yields under solvent- and Cu-free conditions; PS-bpt Pd(II) was reused for successive five cycles. Mikhaylov et al. successfully prepared Pd(II) acyclic diaminocarbene complexes (Pd(II)-ADC) immobilized on a resin surface (Scheme 70 ) [92]; two types of (Pd(II)-ADC) complexes have been reported namely 2aBHA@PS and 2bBHA@PS. The (Pd(II)-ADC) complexes showed good catalytic activity in the SCR (Scheme 71 ) and catalyst could be reused for 8 successive cycles. Pd was immobilized on a porous organic polymer comprising phenanthroline ligands (POP‐Phen) by Dai and co-workers wherein POP‐Phen was obtained by the copolymerization of divinylbenzene (DVB) with vinyl functionalized phenanthroline (Scheme 72 ) [93]. This system performed as a stable catalyst in the Cu-free SCR of aryl halides and phenylacetylene (Scheme 73 ). Ren and co-workers prepared porous organic polymer (POP) through Cu-catalyzed 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of 4-tetra(azidophenyl)methane and 1,4-dialkynylbenzene (Scheme 74 ) [94] and used as a substrate to immobilize Pd(II) on its surface for the fabrication of novel Pd-POP catalyst. It was shown to be an efficient catalyst in the SCR because of high surface area (650 m2/g) and well-dispersed Pd NPs on POP (Scheme 75 ); Pd-POP could be reused successively three to five times. Wang et al. prepared a Pd complex supported onto polysalen-based surface (Scheme 76 ) [95] and the polysalen-Pd catalyst showed high activity in the carbonylative SCR in water (Scheme 77 ). The 81–95% yields of the products and its reuse (five times), clearly indicated the catalyst stability over multiple runs. The preparation of Pd(II) supported on a polymer (TbPo) has been recently described by Bi et al. [96]. The polymer (TbPo) was prepared by Schiff base condensation of o-phenylenediamine and 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (TDTB) in DMF solvent at 150 °C, followed by immobilization of Pd(II) ions on TbPo by reacting TbPo and palladium acetate in dichloromethane solvent at 50 °C (Fig. 1 ). TbPo-Pd(II) was used in the SCR in MeOH/H2O solvent mixture at 80 °C (Fig. 1); and could be reused several times. The formation of poly(NHCs PdII complex) supported on silica NPs, (PdII-NHCs)n@nSiO2, using a multi-step protocol has been reported (Fig. 2 ) [97] and was then explored as a reusable catalyst (for successive 8 times) in the SCR (Scheme 78 ). Mikhaylov et al. have recently studied the fabrication of acyclic diaminocarbene Pd complexes supported on amino-functionalized polystyrene (ADC-PdII) and their stability and catalytic application in the SCR (Scheme 79 ) [98]. The two types of Pd(II)-diaminocarbenes complex studied had protons either at both nitrogen atoms (18) or at one nitrogen atom (19); catalyst (18) was catalytically shown to be more active than (19) because of the enhanced availability of active catalytic sites. Nevertheless, catalyst (19) showed high stability in the SCR. Pd immobilized on a ternary hybrid system containing polyacrylamides (P), halloysite nanotubes (Hal) and β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) was evaluated for the coupling reaction [99]. The catalyst (Pd@Hal-P-CD) was prepared by immobilizing Pd on a support formed by growing polyacrylamide on the functionalized Hal surfaces improved with β-cyclodextrin (Fig. 3 ). Subsequently, Pd@Hal-P-CD was used for the SCR in water/ethanol solvent mixture at 60 °C (Scheme 80 ). Recyclability and leaching studies indicated low Pd leaching due to performance of sustainable surface (Hal-P-CD). Polystyrene supported [PdCl-(SeCSe)] complex was introduced by Mohammadi et al. for SCR [100]. Ps[PdCl-(SeCSe)] catalyst was prepared by reacting 3,5-bis((phenylselanyl)methyl)phenol (20e) with chloromethylated polystyrene support, followed by complexation with PdCl2 (Scheme 81 ). The ligand (20e) was prepared from 5-hydroxy isophthalic acid (20a) via a multi-step reaction. The activity of the Ps[PdCl-(SeCSe)] catalyst was investigated in the SCR (Schemes 82 and 83 ). Sadhasivam et al. reported a covalent porous triazine polymer for the immobilization of Pd NPs (Pd@DASs) [101] which was prepared under solvothermal conditions by the 4,4′,4′'-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tribenzaldehyde (Ss) condensation with 1,4-diaminobenzene (DA) (Scheme 84 ). Pd@DASs was obtained by the Pd(OAc)2 reduction on DASs in presence of hydrazine monohydrate. The obtained catalyst is active for the SCR in water/DMF solvent mixture (Scheme 85 ). Kong et al. described the fabrication of Pd(II) immobilized on microporous organic polymer containing 2,2′-bipyridine (bipy) functional group as the ligand by reacting MOP-bipy and Pd(CH3CN)2Cl2 in MeCN solvent (Scheme 86 ) [102]. This recyclable catalytic system (Pd/MOP-bipy) was then evaluated in the SCR using a 1:1 mixture of H2O/MeOH solvent (Scheme 87 ). In 2019, Sadjadi et al. reported the fabrication of an efficient Pd nanocatalyst by immobilizing them onto a new support (Hal-P-Py) comprising halloysite (Hal) clay and 2-amino pyrimidine functionalized with poly-glycidyl methacrylate (P-Py) (Fig. 4 ) [103]. The catalyst thus obtained showed outstanding catalytic activity in the SCR (Scheme 88 ). The catalyst was capable of being reused for successive 6 cycles. 3 Conclusion The large number of published reports in recent years demonstrates the true potential of polymer-supported Pd complexes in the Sonogashira coupling reactions (SCR) of different aromatic halides with terminal alkynes. In this review, various ligands namely N-acyl-substituted bispyrimidylamine, triazene, dithizone, phosphines, N-heterocyclic carbene, di-(2-pyridyl)methylamine, thiophene, triazole, 2-aminothiazole, tetrazole, ethylenediamine, N,N-bis(naphthylideneimino)diethylenetriamine, thiopseudourea, phenyldithiocarbazate, thiosemi-carbazone, diphenylphosphinoethane, N-methylimidazole, diaminocarbene, 2-methylaminopyridine, furfural, anthranilic acid, azo compounds and Schiff bases are summarized which have been deployed for the preparation of PSP complexes. High catalytic activities and recyclability are the common traits displayed by these PSP complexes in the SCR. The effect of the ligand is reportedly very significant on the catalytic performance of the PSP complexes. Most of these complexes readily convert aryl iodides and bromides to the corresponding coupled products in high yields under varying reaction conditions. Relatively, fewer PSP complexes have been studied in the SCR deploying aromatic chlorides which need to be explored possibly with the introduction of novel and effective PSP complexes; this has been a lingering challenge. Among others, the advancement of more efficient and convenient methods in the future needs to develop: • Exploitation of bio-based polymers such as collagen, lignin, cellulose, cellulose, starch, chitosan, chitin, polypeptide, alginate, pectin, gum etc. for the preparation of PSP complexes. • Deployment of magnetic PSP complexes with high catalytic performance and reusability. • New and eco-friendly methods for the SCR through the use of green solvents. • Operation of simple, mild and one-step methods for the preparation of PSP complexes. coredata.dc:description: Palladium (Pd) complexes supported on the polymers have been widely used in various organic syntheses endeavors because of their thermal stability, high catalytic activities and recyclability. This article provides contemporary advancements in the deployment of polymer-supported Pd complexes (PSP complexes) in Sonogashira coupling reactions (SCR) of halobenzenes with alkynes. Although most of the reports on SCR are focused on aryl iodides, newer methodologies with supported Pd enable the activation of other aryl halides, especially chlorides, which are discussed in this review.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in polymer supported palladium complexes as (nano)catalysts for Sonogashira coupling reaction
